explanation: Refers to the authors of the classic book 'Design Patterns' (Gamma, Helm, Johnson, Vlissides). Often used to label the original OO patterns set.
Programming style organized around objects/classes (encapsulation, inheritance, polymorphism).
Programming style emphasizing pure functions, immutability, and function composition.
Common set of operations for data-driven applications.
A contract for interacting with software components (functions, endpoints, types, protocols).
A packaged set of tools/libraries/docs for building against a platform/service.
The part of an application users interact with (screens, controls, layout, inputs).
Reading/writing data (files, network, streams, devices, stdout/stderr, etc.).
The primary protocol of the web used by browsers and APIs.
Calling a function/method on another machine/process as if it were local (e.g., gRPC, JSON-RPC).
Tree representation of source code structure used by compilers, linters, and code analyzers.
Maps objects/classes to database tables (and vice versa) to simplify persistence.
A system for storing and querying structured data (SQL/NoSQL).
A simple object used to move data between layers/services (often without behavior).
A pattern that provides an abstract interface to a database or persistence mechanism, separating data access logic from business logic.
Architectural pattern separating write commands from read queries and often using different models for each.
Architecture style organizing systems as reusable services with well-defined interfaces (often enterprise-focused).
Concurrency model where independent processes communicate via message passing (often channels).
UI architecture separating data/model, rendering/view, and interaction/controller logic.
UI architecture where Presenter contains most view logic; typically easier to unit test than classic MVC.
UI architecture where ViewModel exposes observable state for data binding.
A .NET UI framework that popularized MVVM patterns with data binding.
Runtime that executes Java bytecode; many languages target it (Java, Kotlin, Scala, etc.).
Microsoft runtime/platform for languages like C#; includes libraries, tooling, and runtimes.
Game architecture pattern organizing entities as IDs with data components and behavior systems (composition over inheritance).
An approach to designing software around the business domain model, emphasizing ubiquitous language, bounded contexts, and domain-centric architecture.
A technique where dependencies are provided to a component instead of being created inside it, improving testability and modularity.
A principle where control flow is inverted so that frameworks or containers call your code rather than your code calling the framework directly.
A queue where messages that cannot be processed successfully are placed for later inspection, retry, or manual handling.
A C++ idiom where resource lifetime is bound to object lifetime, ensuring resources are automatically released when objects go out of scope.
An authorization model where permissions are granted to roles, and users inherit permissions through assigned roles.
An authorization model that evaluates access based on attributes (user, resource, environment) and policies, offering more flexibility than RBAC.
An identity layer on top of OAuth 2.0 that standardizes user authentication and identity claims.
An authorization framework that enables delegated access to resources via tokens.
A catalog of messaging and integration patterns (popularized by Hohpe & Woolf) used to design reliable message-based systems (routers, filters, splitters, aggregators, etc.).
A reliability target for a service over a period of time (e.g., 99.9% availability or 95% of requests under 300ms).
A measured metric that reflects service behavior from a user perspective (latency, error rate, availability). Used to evaluate SLOs.
A formal contract that may include SLOs plus business consequences (credits/penalties). Typically customer-facing.
An observability framework for request-driven services: track request rate, error rate, and request duration (latency).
An observability framework for resources (CPU, memory, disk, network): track utilization, saturation (queued work), and errors.
Average time to restore service after an incident. A key reliability/ops metric.
Average time between service-impacting failures. Often used in reliability engineering.
Maximum acceptable time to restore service after an outage or disaster.
Maximum acceptable amount of data loss measured in time (e.g., 'up to 5 minutes of data loss').
A technique for handling concurrent writes by detecting conflicts with version checks (instead of using locks).
An HTTP mechanism used for caching and optimistic concurrency (If-Match/If-None-Match). Often used as a version identifier for resources.
How long cached data, sessions, tokens, or messages remain valid before expiring automatically.
A pattern where each client type (web/mobile) has a dedicated backend tailored to its UI needs, reducing client complexity and overfetching.
Practice of keeping software deployable at all times through automation; releases are typically a business decision.
Practice of frequently merging changes into a shared branch with automated builds/tests to detect issues early.
A container orchestration platform providing scheduling, scaling, service discovery, and health checks for distributed applications.
A set of guarantees or policies around performance and reliability (priorities, bandwidth, latency, quotas).
An atomic operation used to update a value only if it matches an expected value (common in lock-free programming and OCC-style updates).
Information that can identify a person (directly or indirectly). Important for security, privacy, and compliance design.
Authentication approach allowing a user to log in once and access multiple systems, often implemented with OIDC/SAML.
A standard for exchanging authentication/authorization assertions, commonly used for enterprise SSO.
